Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Exploring the Evolution of an Extreme Makeover in Ferns
Award.AbstractNarration:
The "maidenhair ferns" (belonging to the genus Adiantum) are quintessential ferns -- beautifully dissected, terrestrial, and shade-loving. The "shoe-string ferns" (belonging to a group known as vittarioids) are extremely different: highly simplified, canopy-dwelling epiphytes, with duplicated genomes that exhibit accelerated rates of molecular evolution. Surprisingly, Adiantum and the vittarioids are closely related, comprising a single branch of the tree of life -- a lineage that evidently witnessed an extreme morphological, ecological, and genomic makeover. The proposed research aims to first establish a robust phylogeny for these ferns through analyses of DNA sequence data. Subsequent analyses can then reveal the evolutionary history of the "maidenhair" to "shoestring" fern transformation.


By better characterizing the evolutionary history of this extreme makeover in ferns, this study will better elucidate the evolutionary processes of morphological simplification, ecological transition, genome duplication, and molecular evolutionary rate acceleration. Because all of these processes are frequently encountered across the tree of life, but poorly understood, efforts here to uncover and characterize links among them are broadly relevant. This project encompasses a multidisciplinary training program to promote learning, teaching, and discovery, and is squarely aimed at undergraduate and graduate students interested in the areas of plant systematics, molecular evolution, and phylogenetics. The project will also pursue significant science education and outreach goals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided considerable insight into the fern tree of life. Analyses were conducted to determine whether maidenhair ferns (Adiantum) composed a natural group (Pryer et al., 2016), to examine relationships within the genus (Huiet et al., in review), and to uncover the affinity of a species previously placed in Adiantum (Schuettpelz et al., 2014). The evolutionary history of the closely related vittarioid ferns was also evaluated and a revised generic classification was produced (Schuettpelz et al., 2016). A separate study, the focus of a graduate student thesis, examined the origins of the enigmatic “Appalachian shoestring fern” (Pinson and Schuettpelz, 2016).

Explorations regarding the remarkable vittarioid makeover—involving morphological simplification and a transition to epiphytism—were focused mostly on aspects of molecular evolutionary rate. Work to carefully examine rates for vittarioids uncovered highly significant increases in chloroplast loci that were notably not due to selection (Rothfels and Schuettpelz, 2014). Additional analyses of transcriptomes (spearheaded by a postdoctoral research associate funded by this award) demonstrated that the rate acceleration also extended to the nuclear genome in these plants (Grusz and Schuettpelz, 2016). This discovery inspired additional work to better characterize genome-level changes across the family to which these ferns belong with a using a genome skimming approach (manuscript in preparation).

Two graduate students and two undergraduate students were trained in molecular laboratory techniques and contributed sequence data to this project. One graduate student thesis centered on vittarioid ferns and the project also provided training for two postdoctoral research associates who were able to greatly expand their computational and technical repertoires. Numerous talks were presented at international meetings. Additionally, several visits were made to public middle school classrooms to teach biological concepts relating to this research, including DNA extraction, plant diversity, life cycles, and field identification.
